Subjective: Right low back pain x 1.5 weeks, progressively worsening. Radiates down posterior right thigh and lateral right lower leg to foot. Constant pain, severe. Associated tingling and dull sensation on the outside of the right lower leg. Pain initiated after lifting heavy items at work. Failed max dose paracetamol and ibuprofen. Impact: Unable to sleep for nights due to pain; stopped working (supermarket). No subjective weakness, but pain limits movement. Pertinent Negatives: No issues with bowel or bladder control; normal sensation in perineal ("riding breeches") area. Social: Works in a supermarket, currently on sick leave. ICE: Concerned about needing surgery like a neighbor; asks about needing a CT or MRI scan.
Objective: General: Appears in significant pain, especially with movement (e.g., getting on exam couch). Back Exam: No visible abnormalities. No vertebral tenderness to palpation. Pain localized over right gluteal area. Neurological Exam - Right Leg: Positive straight leg raise test (reproduces radicular pain). Sensation diminished/dull on lateral lower leg and foot compared to left. Neurological Exam - Left Leg: Negative straight leg raise. Normal sensation. Neurological Exam - Bilateral: Strength 5/5 and symmetric in all lower extremity muscle groups, though testing is painful. Reflexes normal and symmetric. Plantar responses normal.
Assessment: Right lumbosacral radicular syndrome, secondary to suspected herniated nucleus pulposus (hernia). No clinical signs of cauda equina syndrome.
Plan: Explained diagnosis of suspected disc herniation causing nerve root compression.
Start Pregabalin for neuropathic pain. Counselled on slow dose titration and potential side effects.
Advised no driving for at least 1 week after starting or changing dose of Pregabalin.
Referral to physiotherapy for guided exercises.
Safety Netting: Return immediately or go to A&E for new/worsening leg weakness, numbness in the groin/buttocks ('saddle' area), or any loss of bowel/bladder control.
Follow-up: Telephone appointment in 1 week to review pain and medication tolerance.
